what-the-hell-does-this-mean.text: What the hell does this mean??

pageProps.body:
Quotient Group Theorems

The existence of this section is regrettable, but unfortunately necessary.

Theorems of normal subgroups

The last section tried its best to plagiarize every reasonably relevant diagram it could off the internet just to build up a visual understanding of what normal subgroups really were. This section will completely destroy any and all traces of that visual understanding and restore our belief that maybe Galois lived a little too long after all.

Lemma. HHH is a normal subgroup of GGG if and only if gH=HggH = HggH=Hg for all g∈Gg\in Gg∈G.

But wait, you say, weren't we using this as the definition of normal subgroups all this time? Yes we were. This is because I'm a rebel at heart who refuses to abide by the demands of everything right and true about mathematics.

Proof.

As it turns out, gH=HggH = HggH=Hg does not define a normal subgroup; ghg−1∈Hghg^{-1} \in Hghg−1∈H does. From that, we have

ghg−1=h1  ⟺  gh=h1g  ⟺  gH=Hgghg^{-1} = h_1 \iff gh = h_1 g \iff gH = Hgghg−1=h1​⟺gh=h1​g⟺gH=Hg

as every ghghgh can be mapped via a bijection to some h1g∈Hgh_1 g\in Hgh1​g∈Hg. (We know already that right and left cosets have the same size, and if we didn't know that, we do now. It is impossible for two different left-coset elements to be equal the same right-coset element. As the sizes of the two sets are the same, and every element in gHgHgH has a unique match in HgHgHg, the two sets are the same.)

Conversely, if gH=HggH = HggH=Hg, then gh=h1ggh = h_1ggh=h1​g for some h,h1∈Hh, h_1 \in Hh,h1​∈H, not necessarily equal. This yields ghg−1=h1∈Hgh g^{-1} = h_1 \in Hghg−1=h1​∈H, satisfying normality.

Lemma. The following subgroups of GGG are normal: {e}\{e\}{e}, GGG, and every subgroup of GGG (if GGG is abelian).

Proof.

For {e}\{e\}{e}, we have geg−1=(ge)g−1=gg−1=e∈{e}geg^{-1} = (ge)g^{-1} = gg^{-1} = e \in \{e\}geg−1=(ge)g−1=gg−1=e∈{e}.

For GGG itself, we have gg1g−1∈Ggg_1 g^{-1} \in Ggg1​g−1∈G by closure.

For abelian groups GGG, any subgroups HHH must also be abelian. Thus for h∈Hh \in Hh∈H, we have ghg−1=gg−1h=eh=h∈Hghg^{-1} = gg^{-1} h = eh = h \in Hghg−1=gg−1h=eh=h∈H.

Lemma. If H≤GH \leq GH≤G has index 222 (is half the size of GGG), then H◃GH \triangleleft GH◃G. (Translator's note: ◃\triangleleft◃ means "is a normal subgroup of")

This is my first time using the fancy symbol. It feels like some sort of milestone.

Proof.

If HHH is index 222, there are only two left cosets of HHH: one equal to HHH itself, one equal to all elements in GGG not in HHH. Of the right cosets of HHH, one is also HHH itself. As the right cosets also partition GGG, the other right coset must be all the elements in GGG but not in HHH - i.e. equal to the remaining left coset. Thus, the right cosets and left cosets of HHH are equal; and by the above lemma, this implies H◃GH \triangleleft GH◃G.

The big one

This title exudes an uncomfortably intimidating aura that I just can't handle properly right now.

Before we get to the big one (note: it's the big one), we batter our hearts with an uncomfortable truth:

Proposition. Let ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H be a group homomorphism between GGG and its subgroup HHH. Then the kernel of ϕ\phiϕ is a normal subgroup of GGG: Ker(ϕ)◃G\text{Ker}(\phi) \triangleleft GKer(ϕ)◃G.

Proof.

By definition, we know that Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) is the set of every g∈Gg\in Gg∈G that maps to eGe_GeG​, the identity of GGG (which is also the identity of HHH). We also know from previous theorems that Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) forms a group. In order for it to be a normal subgroup, we must have

gkg−1∈Ker(ϕ)g k g^{-1} \in \text{Ker}(\phi)gkg−1∈Ker(ϕ)

for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G and k∈Ker(ϕ)k \in \text{Ker}(\phi)k∈Ker(ϕ). This is true by

ϕ(gkg−1)=ϕ(g)ϕ(k)ϕ(g−1)=ϕ(g)eGϕ(g)−1=ϕ(g)ϕ(g)−1=eG\phi(gkg^{-1}) = \phi(g)\phi(k)\phi(g^{-1}) = \phi(g)e_G \phi(g)^{-1} = \phi(g)\phi(g)^{-1} = e_Gϕ(gkg−1)=ϕ(g)ϕ(k)ϕ(g−1)=ϕ(g)eG​ϕ(g)−1=ϕ(g)ϕ(g)−1=eG​

as ϕ(k)=eG\phi(k) = e_Gϕ(k)=eG​ by k∈Ker(ϕ)k \in \text{Ker}(\phi)k∈Ker(ϕ), and HHH and GGG share a binary operation. Thus gkg−1∈Ker(ϕ)gkg^{-1} \in \text{Ker}(\phi)gkg−1∈Ker(ϕ), satisfying the condition for Ker(ϕ)◃G\text{Ker}(\phi) \triangleleft GKer(ϕ)◃G.

Every trombone from the deepest pits of hell and every choir of angels from the highest gardens of heaven all sing the Song of Revelation in unison as they strip away the last veil concealing the ultimate truth:

Theorem. THE (first) ISOMORPHISM THEOREM. Let ϕ\phiϕ be a homomorphism from a group GGG to its subgroup HHH. Then the function

ϕˉ:G/Ker(ϕ)→Im(ϕ)\begin{aligned} \bar\phi: G/\text{Ker}(\phi) \to \text{Im}(\phi) \\ \end{aligned}ϕˉ​:G/Ker(ϕ)→Im(ϕ)​

defined as

ϕˉ(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g)\bar\phi(g\text{Ker}(\phi)) = \phi(g)ϕˉ​(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g)

is well-defined and is a group isomorphism.

What the hell does this mean??

ϕ\phiϕ is a homomorphism from GGG to HHH; Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) is all the elements in GGG that get mapped to the identity eGe_GeG​. Things in GGG are either in Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) or they're not. (Well spotted.) If they are, then that means

ϕ(g1)=eG, g1∈Ker(ϕ)\phi(g_1) = e_G,\ g_1 \in \text{Ker}(\phi)ϕ(g1​)=eG​, g1​∈Ker(ϕ)

If they're not, then that means

ϕ(g2)≠eG, g2∉Ker(ϕ)\phi(g_2) \neq e_G,\ g_2 \notin \text{Ker}(\phi)ϕ(g2​)=eG​, g2​∈/Ker(ϕ)

But at the same time, we also have

ϕ(g1g2)=ϕ(g1)ϕ(g2)=ϕ(g2)ϕ(g1)=eGϕ(g2)=ϕ(g2)\phi(g_1 g_2) = \phi(g_1) \phi(g_2) = \phi(g_2) \phi(g_1) = e_G \phi(g_2) = \phi(g_2)ϕ(g1​g2​)=ϕ(g1​)ϕ(g2​)=ϕ(g2​)ϕ(g1​)=eG​ϕ(g2​)=ϕ(g2​)

as ϕ(g1)=eG\phi(g_1) = e_Gϕ(g1​)=eG​ and any operation with the identity is commutative; the above also arises from Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) being a normal subgroup. If we really take an uncomfortably close look at the expression

g1g2g_1g_2g1​g2​

with g2g_2g2​ encompassing all elements in Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ), we'll see that it's just a way of saying

g1Ker(ϕ)g_1 \text{Ker}(\phi)g1​Ker(ϕ)

the coset of Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) under g1g_1g1​; all elements kkk in this coset satisfy

ϕ(k)=ϕ(g1).\phi(k) = \phi(g_1).ϕ(k)=ϕ(g1​).

Therefore, the cosets of Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) split the group GGG into different cosets based on where ϕ\phiϕ takes each one of these cosets. In other words, the cosets of the normal subgroup Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) splits GGG into different sets based on the image of ϕ\phiϕ:

(Wonderful illustration over at https://www.math3ma.com/blog/the-first-isomorphism-theorem-intuitively)!

All the FIRST ISOMORPHISM THEOREM!!!! says, then, is this: not only do the cosets of Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) split GGG according to the image of ϕ\phiϕ, each unique coset has a one-to-one bijection to an element in the image, establishing the isomorphism

G/Ker(ϕ)≅Im(ϕ)G/\text{Ker}(\phi) \cong \text{Im}(\phi)G/Ker(ϕ)≅Im(ϕ)

via the function

ϕˉ(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g)\bar\phi(g\text{Ker}(\phi)) = \phi(g)ϕˉ​(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g)

or, mapping the coset to its image under ϕ\phiϕ.

Having said that, we're now ready to give a proper

Proof.

First of all, the quotient group G/Ker(ϕ)G/\text{Ker}(\phi)G/Ker(ϕ) 1) exists, and 2) is just the group of cosets gKer(ϕ)g\text{Ker}(\phi)gKer(ϕ) for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G. If the function ϕˉ\bar \phiϕˉ​ defined above is well-defined, then for the same coset gKer(ϕ)g\text{Ker}(\phi)gKer(ϕ) written using an alternate representative as g′Ker(ϕ), g′∈gKer(ϕ)g'\text{Ker}(\phi),\ g' \in g\text{Ker}(\phi)g′Ker(ϕ), g′∈gKer(ϕ), we should have

ϕˉ(g′Ker(ϕ))=ϕ(g′) by definition\bar \phi(g'\text{Ker}(\phi)) = \phi(g') \text{ by definition}ϕˉ​(g′Ker(ϕ))=ϕ(g′) by definition

and also

ϕˉ(g′Ker(ϕ))=ϕˉ(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g)\bar \phi(g'\text{Ker}(\phi)) = \bar \phi(g\text{Ker}(\phi)) = \phi(g)ϕˉ​(g′Ker(ϕ))=ϕˉ​(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g)

as a function shouldn't give something different when you plug in two things that are the same. Thus we need to prove that

ϕ(g′)=ϕ(g)\phi(g') = \phi(g)ϕ(g′)=ϕ(g)

which is true by virtue of g′∈gKer(ϕ)g' \in g\text{Ker}(\phi)g′∈gKer(ϕ), implying that g′=gg1g' = gg_1g′=gg1​ for some g1∈Ker(ϕ)g_1 \in \text{Ker}(\phi)g1​∈Ker(ϕ) and

ϕ(g′)=ϕ(gg1)=ϕ(g)ϕ(g1)=ϕ(g)eG=ϕ(g).\phi(g') = \phi(gg_1) = \phi(g)\phi(g_1) = \phi(g) e_G = \phi(g).ϕ(g′)=ϕ(gg1​)=ϕ(g)ϕ(g1​)=ϕ(g)eG​=ϕ(g).

(This is essentially the same discussion as the intuitive explanation above: every coset of the kernel has the same image under ϕ\phiϕ.)

As such, ϕˉ\bar \phiϕˉ​ is well-defined. As previously mentioned, ϕˉ\bar \phiϕˉ​ is an isomorphism if and only if we have Ker(ϕˉ)={eG/Ker(ϕ)}={eKer(ϕ}\text{Ker}(\bar \phi) = \{e_{G/\text{Ker}(\phi)}\} = \{e\text{Ker}(\phi\}Ker(ϕˉ​)={eG/Ker(ϕ)​}={eKer(ϕ}, Im(ϕˉ)=Im(ϕ)\text{Im}(\bar \phi) = \text{Im}(\phi)Im(ϕˉ​)=Im(ϕ), and ϕˉ\bar\phiϕˉ​ is a homomorphism.

For the kernel property, suppose that ϕˉ(aKer(ϕ))=eG\bar\phi(a\text{Ker}(\phi)) = e_Gϕˉ​(aKer(ϕ))=eG​. Then ϕ(a)=eG\phi(a) = e_Gϕ(a)=eG​, but then a∈Ker(ϕ)a \in \text{Ker}(\phi)a∈Ker(ϕ), making aKer(ϕ)a\text{Ker}(\phi)aKer(ϕ) identical to the identity coset Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ). Thus, the kernel of ϕˉ\bar \phiϕˉ​ is the identity coset only.

For the image property, note that ϕˉ(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g)\bar\phi(g \text{Ker}(\phi)) = \phi(g)ϕˉ​(gKer(ϕ))=ϕ(g) by definition for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G; Im(g)\text{Im}(g)Im(g) is the set of all ϕ(g)\phi(g)ϕ(g), so Im(ϕˉ)\text{Im}(\bar\phi)Im(ϕˉ​) and Im(ϕ)\text{Im}(\phi)Im(ϕ) are indentical.

Finally, ϕˉ\bar\phiϕˉ​ satisfies the definition of a homomorphism as we have

ϕˉ(aKer(ϕ)⋅bKer(ϕ))=ϕˉ(abKer(ϕ))=ϕ(ab)=ϕ(a)ϕ(b)=ϕˉ(aKer(ϕ))ϕˉ(bKer(ϕ))\bar\phi(a \text{Ker}(\phi) \cdot b\text{Ker}(\phi)) = \bar{\phi}(ab\text{Ker}(\phi)) = \phi(ab) = \phi(a) \phi(b) = \bar\phi(a \text{Ker}(\phi)) \bar\phi(b \text{Ker}(\phi))ϕˉ​(aKer(ϕ)⋅bKer(ϕ))=ϕˉ​(abKer(ϕ))=ϕ(ab)=ϕ(a)ϕ(b)=ϕˉ​(aKer(ϕ))ϕˉ​(bKer(ϕ))

where ⋅\cdot⋅ denotes the binary operation under a set of cosets. Therefore, ϕˉ\bar\phiϕˉ​ is an isomorphism from G/Ker(ϕ)G/\text{Ker}(\phi)G/Ker(ϕ) to Im(ϕ)\text{Im}(\phi)Im(ϕ). □\square□

Simple groups

Let's end things with a simple definition:

Definition. A simple group is a group with no normal subgroups aside from the trivial subgroup {e}\{e\}{e} and itself.

Simple subgroups are like the prime numbers of group theory, and I mean it in every way: they're the building blocks of all non-simple groups, some of them are so complex we still have a gazillion unresolved open problems about them, and mathematicians get divorced over obsessing over them to this day.
